items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Swimming's governing body says it will debut a new "open category" for transgender swimmers at the World Cup in Berlin in October. Last year, World Aquatics voted to ban transgender athletes from competing in elite women's competitions at major events. World Aquatics says the open category will feature in 50-metre and 100-metre races across all strokes. It says more events could be added.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Open category' added for transgender swimmers at World Cup

children.content: Swimming's governing body says it will debut a new "open category" for transgender swimmers at the
World Cup in Berlin in October.
Last year, World Aquatics
voted to ban transgender athletes
from competing in elite women's competitions at major events.
World Aquatics says the open category will feature in 50-metre and 100-metre races across all strokes.
It says more events could be added.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukrainian officials say Russia is attacking their grain storage facilities, with air strikes damaging silos and warehouses at a port on the Danube river. There's been no comment from Moscow. US State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel says Russia's attacks on Ukrainian port infrastructure are escalating food shortages. "[Russian President Vladimir] Putin simply does not care about global food security," he says. "Such actions by the Kremlin negatively affect Ukrainian farmers and all those around the world who are most vulnerable to food insecurity."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US condemns Russia's continued attacks on Ukraine's grain infrastructure

children.content: Ukrainian officials say Russia is attacking their grain storage facilities, with air strikes damaging silos and warehouses at a port on the Danube river.
There's been no comment from Moscow.
US State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel says Russia's attacks on Ukrainian port infrastructure are escalating food shortages.
"[Russian President Vladimir] Putin simply does not care about global food security," he says.
"Such actions by the Kremlin negatively affect Ukrainian farmers and all those around the world who are most vulnerable to food insecurity."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's what Anthony Albanese had to say about the Matildas after last night's game, as they prepare for the weekend's clash with Sweden for third place: You've shown incredible skill, ferocity and flair, and a camaraderie that defines what it means to play team sport. You've given us all moments and memories that will last a lifetime. Cortnee Vine rocketing the ball into the net in the final penalty against France. Mackenzie Arnold's brick-wall saves. Sam Kerr leading the team on and off the field. Every single Matilda has brought us joy throughout this World Cup. And I have no doubt that the next generation of Matildas were watching. We'll all be cheering for you on Saturday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime minister calls the Matildas 'an absolute inspiration'

children.content: Here's what Anthony Albanese had to say about the Matildas after last night's game, as they prepare for the weekend's clash with Sweden for third place:
You've shown incredible skill, ferocity and flair, and a camaraderie that defines what it means to play team sport.
You've given us all moments and memories that will last a lifetime.
Cortnee Vine rocketing the ball into the net in the final penalty against France.
Mackenzie Arnold's brick-wall saves.
Sam Kerr leading the team on and off the field.
Every single Matilda has brought us joy throughout this World Cup.
And I have no doubt that the next generation of Matildas were watching.
We'll all be cheering for you on Saturday.

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: The rejection of a rental freeze at yesterday's National Cabinet means the push from the Greens has hit a dead end. Will the party join the Coalition to vote down the government's $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund? We'll see, writes David Speers.

title.children: Rental freeze hits a dead end, squashed by the orthodox view

image.altText: Three women looking very sad huddled close together.

items.synopsis: The peak body for WA's family violence services calls for the state government to review how its systems could better protect alleged domestic abuse victims and prevent future deaths.

title.children: 'Call for action': Emotional vigil hears calls to overhaul WA's domestic violence support agencies

image.altText: A woman and two children walk down a runway with an small plane behind them.

items.synopsis: It's something we rarely hear about in Australia – for good reason – but there are people living in witness protection programs across the nation.

title.children: New name, new history, new location: Is witness protection really like what we see on TV?

image.altText: Will Forte as Reggie behind the wheel of a car with a dog in the background. Doug looks exasperated

items.synopsis: Starring Will Ferrell, Jamie Foxx and Australian actor Isla Fisher, Strays is an R-rated comedy about friendship that will have you howling with laughter.

title.children: Strays will leave you roaring with laughter and gasping in disbelief

image.altText: People walk across a street.

items.synopsis: Negativity on Wall Street overnight is likely to send the local market lower after the US Federal Reserve flagged potential interest rate rises, noting inflation was still a "significant" risk to the economy. Follow live.

title.children: 'Significant' US inflation risk stokes rate hike concerns, ASX to fall ahead of latest unemployment data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Last month's unemployment rate fell slightly to 3.5%, surprising many an economist who had expected it to remain unchanged at 3.6%. The most recent ABS data showed that 33,000 people gained work in June, with hours worked also increasing — showing more Australians were working full-time. So what can we expect from today's data? Analysts from NAB and Commonwealth Bank are expecting a slight uptick in the unemployment rate, and expect it to return to 3.6%. CBA forecasts around 20,000 new jobs being created, while NAB expects employment growth to come in around 15,000. It's no secret that the RBA wants to see unemployment go higher, and noted that there were "some signs that the labour market was at a turning point". The RBA expects an unemployment rate of 3.9% by the fourth quarter, so a gradual lift between now and then is on the cards. All that said though, unemployment can be volatile, and it has defied just about everyone's expectations in the past — we'll find out whether that labour market resilience will continue a little later this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What can we expect the unemployment rate to do today?

children.content: Last month's
unemployment rate fell slightly to 3.5%
, surprising many an economist who had expected it to remain unchanged at 3.6%.
The most recent ABS data showed that 33,000 people gained work in June, with hours worked also increasing — showing more Australians were working full-time.
So what can we expect from today's data?
Analysts from NAB and Commonwealth Bank are expecting a slight uptick in the unemployment rate, and expect it to
return to 3.6%
CBA forecasts around 20,000 new jobs
being created, while NAB expects employment growth to come in around 15,000.
It's no secret that the RBA wants to see unemployment go higher, and noted that there were
"some signs that the labour market was at a turning point"
The
RBA expects an unemployment rate of 3.9% by the fourth quarter
, so a gradual lift between now and then is on the cards.

All that said though, unemployment can be volatile, and it has defied just about everyone's expectations in the past — we'll find out whether that labour market resilience will continue a little later this morning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to Thursday, August 17 — you're reading the ABC's business and markets blog. It was a disappointing night for the Matildas and that translated across to the foreign markets overnight. Wall Street finished lower, with the S & P 500, Dow Jones and Nasdaq all falling after the US Federal Reserve's minutes from their July meeting were released, which showed the central bank was divided on the way forward with interest rates. The Fed's policymakers unanimously agreed to lift interest rates to the 5.25-5.5% range in July to bring inflation down, but the minutes show that they remain open to the possibility of more rate rises. "Most participants continued to see significant upside risks to inflation, which could require further tightening of monetary policy, " the minutes noted. To say that was a downer for the markets would be an understatement — they had thought the Fed was done with rate rises, especially since US inflation figures are heading in the right direction. The Fed's next meeting isn't until mid-September though, and even with the release of the minutes overnight, investors are still expecting the central bank will leave rates unchanged. Meanwhile in the UK, their latest inflation figures came in as expected at 6.8% in July, down from 7.9% in June Back home and it appears that overseas negativity will be contagious, with futures trending down, suggesting the local market is in for another day in the red. And it's a big day for data — namely the latest unemployment figures, which will drop at 11:30am AEST. Plus we've also got more big company earnings coming out today, with Telstra, Blackmores and Amcor among those reporting. If you're feeling worse for wear this morning after staying up watching our Tillies (🙋‍♀️), consider this your permission slip to put an extra shot in your coffee before settling in to see how the day unfolds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A negative day likely on the ASX ahead of latest unemployment data
